newsitem.title: GERMANY: Communes not opposed to RWE share plan.
newsitem.headline: Communes not opposed to RWE share plan.

text.p: Local governments owning stock in German diversified utility RWE AG said on Saturday they did not fundamentally oppose the company's plans to strip them of their multiple voting rights.
"From our point of view there isn't a categorical 'no', but there also isn't a 'yes'," Walter Mende, head of the VkA group of communal RWE shareholders, told Die Welt newspaper.
RWE announced this week it wanted to scrap multiple voting rights held mainly by 60 local governments which control the company despite owning only 30 percent of its equity capital.
The shareholding arrangement, which dates back to 1924, is seen by investors as an anachronism. RWE's announcement of the planned change sent its stock soaring 10 percent on Thursday.
Mende said a decision on the shareholding change could not be expected before October, and the fate of the proposal would only be finally sealed at RWE's annual shareholders' meeting.
Under the RWE proposal, the special shares -- which each carry 20 votes -- would be converted into ordinary shares.
In order to maintain the number of voting shares in the company, RWE would also offer to convert preferred stock into ordinary shares and charge a premium.
The premium would then go to compensate the holders of the special shareholders -- many of which desperately need a cash infusion to shore up their finances.
Mende told Die Welt that if the communes were to give up their voting rights "then we would have to talk about a fair price". He said he expected the talks to be long and difficult.
RWE shares closed a touch lower on Friday at 86.70 marks, while preferreds tumbled 3.45 marks to 71.25 marks.
